The cells of Brachybacterium conglomeratum are coccoid or short-rod shaped, and they tend to form aggregates or conglomerates, which is the basis for the species name "conglomeratum." The cells are typically 0.5-1.0 µm in diameter and 1.0-2.0 µm in length.

Brachybacterium conglomeratum is chemoheterotrophic, meaning it requires organic compounds as a source of carbon and energy for growth. It is able to grow on a variety of simple carbohydrates and amino acids.

Phylogenetically, Brachybacterium conglomeratum is closely related to other members of the genus Brachybacterium, which are known to be found in diverse environments, including soil, water, and the human skin microbiome.

The genome of Brachybacterium conglomeratum has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and adaptations to its environmental niche. Further research on this species may contribute to our understanding of the role of Brachybacterium bacteria in various ecosystems.
